disclaimer: These evidence examples are community suggestions to help with FedRAMP compliance automation. They are NOT official FedRAMP guidance. Always verify requirements with official FedRAMP documentation at https://fedramp.gov

sources.artifact: KSI compliance matrix with status for each indicator

evidence.tip: Scans must cover all assets: VMs, containers, serverless, and web apps. FedRAMP requires authenticated scanning for accurate results. Verify scan coverage matches your asset inventory.

sources.description: GCP Security Command Center vulnerability findings

evidence.tip: FedRAMP remediation SLAs: Critical/High within 30 days, Medium within 90 days, Low within 180 days. Track Mean Time to Remediate (MTTR) and percentage meeting SLA.

sources.description: GCP SCC open vulnerability count over time
DefectDojo active findings with SLA tracking

evidence.tip: Demonstrate risk reduction over time. Show trending charts of open vulnerabilities by severity. Sudden spikes may indicate new attack surface or scanning gaps.

sources.command: gcloud scc findings list --organization=<org> --filter='category="VULNERABILITY" AND state="ACTIVE"' --format='table(finding.severity)' | sort | uniq -c

evidence.tip: Verify continuous/automated scanning is enabled (not just periodic). Check that all asset types are covered and new resources are automatically enrolled.

sources.artifact: Security inbox procedures and monitoring evidence
Incident Response Plan with FedRAMP ICP integration

evidence.description: Role-based training completion for privileged users

KSI-CED-04.name: Incident Response and Disaster Recovery Education

evidence.tip: Look for overly permissive rules: 0.0.0.0/0 ingress, any-to-any rules, or unused open ports. Both ingress AND egress should be restricted to least privilege.

sources.description: Security group rules with ingress/egress details
GCP firewall rules with source ranges

evidence.tip: Scan for unintended public exposure. Any resource reachable from 0.0.0.0/0 should be explicitly justified in documentation.
Verify network segmentation between security zones (DMZ, app tier, data tier). Document trust boundaries and justify any cross-zone traffic.

sources.artifact: Network architecture diagram showing security zones and trust boundaries

sources.command: aws securityhub get-findings --filters '{"ProductName":[{"Value":"AWS Foundational Security Best Practices","Comparison":"EQUALS"}]}'

evidence.tip: Verify policy REQUIRES phishing-resistant MFA (FIDO2, WebAuthn, passkeys, PIV/CAC). SMS, TOTP, and push notifications do NOT qualify as phishing-resistant under FedRAMP 20x.

sources.description: Okta MFA policy - check for WebAuthn/FIDO2 requirement
Entra ID authentication strength - look for 'phishingResistant' strength
Conditional Access policies with authentication strength requirements
List MFA devices (check for hardware keys vs virtual)
GCP Cloud Identity group membership with 2SV status
Google Workspace Admin SDK - user 2SV enrollment
Duo Admin API - user enrollment and auth methods

evidence.tip: 100% of users must have phishing-resistant MFA enrolled. Generate reports showing enrollment coverage and the specific MFA type per user.

sources.command: aws iam generate-credential-report && aws iam get-credential-report --output text --query 'Content' | base64 -d
sources.description: IAM credential report - check mfa_active and hardware_mfa columns
User MFA enrollment - check embedded factors for WebAuthn
CrowdStrike Identity - MFA status across IdPs

evidence.tip: Monitor for successful authentications that bypass MFA or use non-compliant methods. Alert on any fallback to SMS/TOTP.

sources.description: Entra ID sign-in logs - filter by authenticationMethodsUsed
CloudTrail console login events with MFA info

evidence.tip: SIEM must be centralized and tamper-resistant. Verify all log sources are connected and retention meets FedRAMP requirements (typically 1 year online, 3 years archived for moderate).

sources.description: Splunk data inputs - verify all critical sources

evidence.tip: Document all systems in scope and verify each has log forwarding enabled. Missing sources = compliance gaps.

sources.artifact: Log source matrix mapping systems to SIEM data sources

evidence.tip: Monitor SIEM itself for gaps in ingestion. Alert on missing data or ingestion delays.

sources.artifact: Log source inventory with event types

sources.artifact: DR test execution records and results

evidence.description: Secret management policy and rotation settings
evidence.tip: Verify automatic rotation is enabled. For high-impact systems, secrets should rotate at least every 90 days. Service account keys should rotate more frequently (30-60 days).

sources.description: GCP Secret Manager with rotation config
Vault mount configuration and TTL settings

evidence.description: Secret access and rotation audit logs
evidence.tip: Monitor for unauthorized access attempts, failed retrievals, and verify rotation events occur on schedule. Alert on any manual secret access by humans (should be rare).
Maintain a complete inventory of all secrets with clear ownership. Identify any secrets that haven't rotated recently or have no defined owner - these are compliance risks.

sources.description: GCP Secret Manager inventory with labels

evidence.tip: Continuously scan for exposed secrets in code, logs, and configuration. Any detected exposure requires immediate rotation and incident response.
